A funny thing I've learned is that if you are technical founder with an impressive resume, it's quite difficult to actually get any of these jobs - everyone thinks you're overqualified.

If you're building an AI agent to automate some job, like a payroll specialist, the hardcore move is to just go get that job and do it for a while.

We call this "going undercover", and we're seeing more of the top founders do it. It's the best way to learn what to build.
"Ask yourself, what risk are you avoiding right now because you're comfortable?" https://t.co/2KxSNO4i6I

RT @ChadRigetti: Whether you are just getting started in your career, a second time founder, or something else altogether -- if you want to…

Many of the best founding teams were all technical.

We often see technical founders searching for a non-technical founder because someone said they need one.  They find it a huge relief to learn they can work with their friend who's an engineer.
If you are a technical founder, you do not need a non-technical cofounder.
